intro: Campium foxworthyi, commonly known as the Florida sand cherry, is a rare shrub native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Rosaceae family and is characterized by its small, white flowers and oval-shaped leaves. The plant typically grows in sandy soils and is adapted to coastal and dune environments. It produces small, red berries that are an important food source for local wildlife. Due to its limited range and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species.
